question_text: A 19-year-old man is evaluated during a routine physical examination. He reports one previous episode of syncope during an acute illness.ECG is shown.
question_stem: Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
critique: The most likely diagnosis is Brugada syndrome (Option B). Most episodes of syncope are attributed to benign causes, such as vasovagal syncope or volume depletion; however, the combination of syncope with illness and this ECG pattern (right bundle branch block and 2-mm ST-segment elevation in the precordial leads) strongly suggests Brugada syndrome in this patient. Patients with this inherited arrhythmia syndrome, which is more common among individuals of South Asian descent, are at increased risk for syncope, ventricular fibrillation, or sudden death during sleep or with fever.Arrhythmogenic right ventricular cardiomyopathy (ARVC) and hypertrophic cardiomyopathy (HCM) may cause syncope in young patients; however, the syncope is more commonly exertional. Furthermore, the ECG manifestations in each of these entities are different, with anterior precordial repolarization abnormalities with or without epsilon waves in ARVC and left ventricular hypertrophy and repolarization abnormalities in HCM.
